title: First steps: роЕ, роЖ, роо, рок, роЯ
pages:
Welcome! Let's learn Tamil.

Tamil ( родрооро┐ро┤рпН - actual pronunciation Thamil, also romanized as Thamizh) is a classical ancient language!
It's one of the longest-surviving classical languages, with a written history of over 2,000 years.

This basics module introduces the Tamil alphabet.

There are 247 letters in the Tamil alphabet, and while this may seem daunting at first, it follows a pattern that gets easier to follow as we go along.

There are only 30 basic letters - 12 vowels and 18 consonants.
The rest of the alphabet is derived from these 30 basic letters with just a few patterns.
In the first lesson, we will learn 2 vowels and 3 consonants.

The first vowel of the tamil alphabet is роЕ , pronounced like the A in 'allow'.

Practice tracing it below.

Whenever I introduce a new letter, remember to pronounce it out of your mouth and listen to the sounds provided so you get used to saying it and recognizing it. It's really important to practice these sounds to learn efficiently!
The second vowel is simply the long version of роЕ, which is written as роЖ. Simply pronounce it longer as роЕ!
The first consanant we will learn is роорпН, pronounced like the English letter M.

Next we will see how consonants are combined with vowels.
With the vowels we have learned so far - роЕ (a) & роЖ (aa),
There are three ways this consonant роорпН shows up:
роорпН (m), роо (ma), and рооро╛ (maa)
роорпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

роорпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

роо: When it is written without a dot, it defaults to the роЕ vowel, resulting in the 'ma' sound. роорпН + роЕ = роо

роорпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

роо: When it is written without a dot, it defaults to the роЕ vowel, resulting in the 'ma' sound. роорпН + роЕ = роо

рооро╛: When "ро╛" is present after a consonant, it is the роЖ vowel, resulting in the 'maa' sound.
роорпН + роЖ = рооро╛
The next consonant is the рокрпН, pronounced like the English letter P.
Now let's look at combining рокрпН with vowels. The same rules that apply to роорпН (m), роо (ma), рооро╛ (maa), also apply to рокрпН (p), рок (pa), рокро╛ (paa).
рокрпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

рокрпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

рокрпН combined with роЕ makes рок (pa). рокрпН + роЕ = рок

рокрпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

рокрпН combined with роЕ makes рок (pa). рокрпН + роЕ = рок

рокрпН combined with роЖ makes рокро╛ (paa). рокрпН + роЖ = рокро╛
The next consonant we learn is the роЯрпН, pronounced like the English letter T.
Now let's look at combining роЯрпН with vowels. The same pattern we saw with роорпН (m), роо (ma), рооро╛ (maa) and рокрпН (p), рок (pa), рокро╛ (paa) continue here.
роЯрпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

роЯрпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

роЯрпН combined with роЕ makes роЯ (ta). роЯрпН + роЕ = роЯ

роЯрпН: When there is a dot on top of the consonant, it signifies no vowel after the sound.

роЯрпН combined with роЕ makes роЯ (ta). роЯрпН + роЕ = роЯ

роЯрпН combined with роЖ makes роЯро╛ (taa). роЯрпН + роЖ = роЯро╛

Note: In Tamil, hard consonant sounds like рок and роЯ (and few others you will learn in subsequent lessons) will be pronounced differently based on the context. For example,

рок can represent the sound of pa or ba.
роЯ can represent the sound of ta or da.

You will learn this better as you get familiar with more words.
Now, let's put what you've learned to practice!

title: consonants: the sequel роЪ, роХ, род
pages: Introducing three letters this lesson just to keep it simple and expand on the usage of the роЕ and роЖ vowels.
роХрпН: pronounced somewhere between English K and G.
роХрпН combined with роЕ makes роХ (ka). роХрпН + роЕ = роХ Depending upon the context, it can represent ka, ga or at rare times even ha sounds.
роХрпН combined with роЖ makes роХро╛ (kaa). роХрпН + роЖ = роХро╛
родрпН: pronounced like 'th' in English. It's the 'th' used in Tamil!
родрпН combined with роЕ makes род (tha). родрпН + роЕ = род. Depending upon the context, it can sound tha or dha.
родрпН combined with роЖ makes родро╛ (thaa). родрпН + роЖ = родро╛
роЪрпН: pronounced like 'ch' in English.
роЪрпН combined with роЕ makes роЪ (cha). роЪрпН + роЕ = роЪ Depending upon the context, it can represent cha or sa sounds.
роЪрпН combined with роЖ makes роЪро╛ (chaa). роЪрпН + роЖ = роЪро╛

title: knee! роЗ, рой, рог, рои
pages: This level might be a little tricky for new learners who have no Tamil experience whatsoever. I'll try and take it slow!
We will learn a new vowel and 3 consonants in this lesson.
Let's get into the consonants first: рой, рог, рои. They all sound like the same English letter: N.

Why on earth would Tamilians make three different letters for the same sound? Well, as we continue learning the language, it's just one of those rules that become more common and that we have to deal with.
So, lets compare the two that look similar, рой and рог. These two actually do have a slightly different pronounciation that can be hard to miss!

Notice where your tongue goes when you pronounce 'n'. The difference between the two looped (рой) and three looped (рог) is where you place your tongue. For the two looped you place it next to your teeth, and the three looped is placed farther back on the roof of your mouth.

Tongue placement is important when pronouncing certain consonants in Tamil. Don't worry about it too much, I will expand on this in later lessons. However, it is still important to know that there are two different types of 'n'. I will admit, however, when you hear it there just seems to be no difference at all, and are easy to mix up!
The last 'n', рои, is pronounced exactly like the two looped 'n' (рой) but is only used in the beginning of words and right before род. рой and рог will NEVER come at the beginning of a word!
Pay attention to correct pronunciation, and try to notice where the different Ns are placed while learning these new words!

Now, let's introduce the new vowel: роЗ, pronounced like the i in 'bin'.

Practice drawing this vowel multiple times, it might be a little tricky at first!
To combine роЗ with consonants, you add an arc from on top to the bottom right of a consonant. рокро┐ (pi), рооро┐ (mi), родро┐ (thi), роХро┐(ki) , роЯро┐(di)
Now let's review what you learned!

title: ear! роИ, ро░, ро▒
pages: In this lesson, we will learn a new vowel and 2 consonants.
New vowel: роИ, the longer version of роЗ.
To combine it with consonants, you add a loop at the top at the same place where роЗ's line was.
The next two consanants are both a version of R. Similar to the last lesson, these two vary in their pronounciation depending on where you place your tongue.

ро░ is the 'softer version', ро▒ is the 'harder version', which just means you place your tongue farther in. (when ро░рпН with the dot is typed, the bottom line is often ommited as it's not really necessary; however, when writing, it is good practice to include it.)
It's important that ро▒ has another way to being pronounced, when it's placed like so: ро▒рпНро▒. This makes the ро▒рпН be pronounced like a t, so it makes a 'tr' sound.
While this next set of words doesn't have a double ро▒, there will be some in the future, so watch out for those!
With the introduction of ро░ and ро▒, we can also expand on the рой, рог, and рои rules from before.
рой is called ро▒ройрпНройроХро░роорпН (rannagaram) as it is used when paired with ро▒ (as ройрпНро▒).
рог is called роЯрогрпНрогроХро░роорпН (dannagaram) for the same reason (as рогрпНроЯ)
And remember, only рои goes in the beginning of (real) words, and is called родроирпНроироХро░роорпН (thannagaram) because it shows up in the middle of words as роирпНрод.

As you recognize more and more words, the pattern becomes more evident and easier to tell which one to use when hearing a new word, so don't worry if you don't fully understand yet. I'll expand on this concept in a later lesson!

title: lilac роР, ро│, ро▓, ро┤
pages: In this lesson, we will learn a new vowel and 3 consonants.
New vowel: роР, pronounced ai.

To combine роР with consonants, you add
рпИ
character before the consonant.

рокрпИ (pai), роорпИ (mai), роЯрпИ (tai), роХрпИ (kai), родрпИ (thai), роЪрпИ (chai), роирпИ (nai), рогрпИ(nai), ройрпИ(nai), ро░рпИ(rai), ро▒рпИ(rai)

The new consonants we are going to learn in this lesson represent L sound.
Similar to рой, рог, рои and ро░, ро▒, the L sounds have three variations in Tamil: ро▓, ро│, ро┤

It is important to learn the right pronunciation of these different sounds. If you use the wrong version, the meaning of some words could be entirely different. Pronunciation is important so that you can write words out correctly.
Pronunciation in these consonants is dependent on tongue placement. Practice putting your tongue in these different places and pronouncing these consonants.
ро▓ is pronounced at the front of the mouth, at the tip of your front teeth.

ро┤ is pronounced by flipping the tongue all the way to the back. The ро┤ sound originated in Tamil, and as it is pronounced so differently, it's mostly romanized as zha. In this course we're romanizing all three as the same, but you still need to pronounce them differently!

ро│ is pronounced in the middle of these two. A way to differentiate between ро│рпН and ро┤рпН is the two palates of the roof of the mouth: the rough palate is where ро│рпН is pronounced and the soft palate is where ро┤рпН is pronounced. Run your tongue between these palates to feel the difference.

title: wavy тИ┐тИ┐ роО, роП, роп, ро╡
pages: In this lesson we will learn two new vowels and two new consonants.
роО pronounced like E in 'enter'
роП (pronounced like ae) is longer version of роО.
Compared to the english pronunciation of these vowels, open/widen up your mouth when pronouncing these vowels in Tamil.

To combine роО with consonants, you add рпЖ character before the consonant.
рокрпЖ (pe), роорпЖ (me), роЯрпЖ (te), роХрпЖ (ke), родрпЖ (the), роЪрпЖ (che), роирпЖ (ne), рогрпЖ (ne), ройрпЖ (ne), ро░рпЖ (re), ро▒рпЖ (re), ро▓рпЖ (le), ро│рпЖ (le), ро┤рпЖ (le)

title: ow! роТ, роУ, роФ
pages: In this lesson we will learn three new vowels.

New vowels in this lesson are
роТ pronounced like the first O in 'tomato'
роУ (pronounced like second O in 'tomato') is longer version of роТ.
роФ (pronounced like ou in 'sound' or 'ow!')

To combine роТ with consonants, you add рпЖ character before the consonant and ро╛ character after the consonant.
For example рокрпК (po), роорпК (mo), роЯрпК (to), роХрпК (ko), родрпК (tho), роЪрпК (cho), роирпК (no), рогрпК (no), ройрпК (no), ро░рпК (ro), ро▒рпК (ro), ро▓рпК (lo), ро│рпК (lo), ро┤рпК (lo)

To combine роУ with consonants, you add рпЗ character before the consonant and ро╛ character after the consonant.
For example рокрпЛ (pO), роорпЛ (mO), роЯрпЛ (tO), роХрпЛ (kO), родрпЛ (thO), роЪрпЛ (chO), роирпЛ (nO), рогрпЛ (nO), ройрпЛ (nO), ро░рпЛ (rO), ро▒рпЛ (rO), ро▓рпЛ (lO), ро│рпЛ (lO), ро┤рпЛ (lO)

To combine роФ with consonants, you add рпЖ character before the consonant and ро│ character after the consonant.
For example рокрпМ (pou), роорпМ (mou), роЯрпМ (tou), роХрпМ (kou), родрпМ (thou), роЪрпМ (chou), роирпМ (nou), рогрпМ (nou), ройрпМ (nou), ро░рпМ (rou), ро▒рпМ(rou), ро▓рпМ(lou), ро│рпМ(lou), ро┤рпМ(lou)

title: ginger ЁЯлЪ роЩрпН, роЮрпН
pages:
In this lesson we will learn two new consonants.

With this lesson, we have learned all the consonants.

We will do a review after the next lesson.
роЩрпН pronounced like the n in 'ringing' or 'angle'
роЮрпН, pronounced like n in 'angel'

роЩрпН and роЮрпН is most commonly used with their respective friendly letters: роЩрпН appears with роХ letters to make the ing sound, and роЮрпН appears with роЪ letters to make nj sounds.

You almost never see роЩрпН with another vowel, and роЮрпН is usually only paired with роЕ or роЖ as роЮ and роЮро╛.
From this lesson, you only need to know 4 sounds: роЩрпН (ng), роЮрпН (nj), роЮ (nya), роЮро╛ (nyaa) Let's review what we learned in this lesson!

title: Classification

Another important thing to note is each consonsant in ро╡ро▓рпНро▓ро┐ройроорпН has a corresponding consonant in роорпЖро▓рпНро▓ро┐ройроорпН. They almost always appear together.

When they do, the hard sounding consonant changes its sound to be a bit soft.

For example, роХ in роХро░роЯро┐ sounds like a regular ро╡ро▓рпНро▓ро┐ройроорпН роХ(ka).

But роХ in родроЩрпНроХроорпН sounds softer (ga) since it appears together with its corresponding роорпЖро▓рпНро▓ро┐ройроорпН (роЩрпН).

This rule applies to all hard consonants and their corresponding soft consonants. Try pronouncing them alone and then together and observe they sound softer.
